answers.answer: Serenity,There are prexisting factors that may contribute to raised LDL levels, such as obesity (20 lbs overweight), smoking, diet, family history of cardiovascular disease, hypertension, diabetes and age, etc.LDL is considered the bad "cholesterol" in which the plaque can build up against your arterial walls.  The higher the LDL the greater risk you or anyone for heart disease.As far as damage of the myelin that may contribute to an increase of LDL levels, cholesterol is the major component of the myelin sheath and I would assume that can increase your "bad" cholesterol.However, I would wonder if you have any of those risk factors mentioned previously in addition to your condition with MS is adding to the raised levels.I'm sorry I can't be of more help in this matter, but it appears that my brain is not functioning as well as I want it to.  I had a plan on how I was going to answer this and somehow ended up lost in my own words.Lisa

question: Hi I was wondering if any of you have raised ldl levels in blood tests, app it is a side effect of the nerves trying to repair the damaged areas, I dunno if this is accurate but the pathologist seems to think so, any ideas.
title: Raised LDL levels in blood
